the_headline: Young, Confident and Flying, Virus Be Damned

the_snippet: Every time he opens his mouth, he puts the American people at risk.
the_headline: Trump Should Just Stop Talking about Coronavirus

the_snippet: When theaters shuttered, Shakespeare turned to poetry.
the_headline: Broadway Is Closed. Write Poems Instead.

the_snippet: The host of “Trish Regan Primetime” told viewers this week that concerns about the coronavirus were “yet another attempt to impeach the president.”
the_headline: Fox Business Benches Trish Regan After Outcry Over Coronavirus Comments

the_snippet: The coronavirus is pushing down growth and risking recession.
the_headline: We Need Real Economic Stimulus

the_snippet: President Trump, surrounded by business leaders, said coronavirus tests would soon be more widely available. Investors pushed the market up nearly 10 percent.
the_headline: Stocks Surge After Trump Promises Speedier Coronavirus Testing

the_snippet: As bad news continued to mount, the coronavirus sucked the fun and money out of Florida’s annual spring break.
the_headline: Spring Break Was in Full Mode, And Then It Got Canceled.

the_snippet: The Trump administration widened the travel ban to include the United Kingdom and Ireland. Here’s a guide on which countries are affected, and the changes to flights already occurring.
the_headline: The Extended Travel Ban: What It Means for Air Travelers

the_snippet: Consumers preparing to hole up at home are adding wine, beer and spirits to their list of must-haves, but shopkeepers worry it’s just the storm before the calm.
the_headline: Those Long Lines? People Stocking the Liquor Cabinet, Not the Pantry

the_snippet: For many events, it’s not too late to get your money back.
the_headline: Ticketholders Seek Refunds as Coronavirus Prompts Mass Cancellations

the_snippet: Large-denomination bills were in such high demand this week that at least one Bank of America branch wasn’t able to satisfy some customers pulling out tens of thousands of dollars at a time.
the_headline: A Bank in Midtown Is Cleaned Out of $100 Bills

the_snippet: “We are not prepared,” one doctor said. New York City’s hospitals may be moving too slowly as the outbreak spreads, experts say.
the_headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.: Will a Surge in Patients Overwhelm Hospitals?

the_snippet: Golf’s first major tournament of the season was postponed indefinitely on Friday because of the spread of coronavirus.
the_headline: With Masters Postponed, Not Canceled, Golfers Hope for a Do-Over

the_snippet: Mr. Wuorinen won a Pulitzer Prize at 31 and went on to write a large body of mainly atonal works, including the opera “Brokeback Mountain.”
the_headline: Charles Wuorinen, Uncompromising Modernist Composer, Dies at 81

the_snippet: The “Fast & Furious” spinoff starring Dwayne Johnson and Jason Statham airs on HBO, while veteran comedians perform on Showtime.

the_snippet: There are two kinds of cracks in old lath and plaster walls. Both can be repaired, but one is a much more serious problem.
the_headline: How to Fix Those Cracking, Crumbling Plaster Walls

the_snippet: An official said she hoped that up to 5,000 migrants would participate in the voluntary scheme, which had caveats.
the_headline: E.U. to Offer 2,000 Euros to Migrants in Greece to Go Home

the_snippet: Facing pressure from parents, conflicting messages from experts and initial silence from the federal government, superintendents began making their own decisions to close.
the_headline: Administration Offers Guidance to Schools as They Shut Down on Their Own

the_snippet: As China grappled with the coronavirus, it kept the masks it made. Now that other nations need them, pressure is rising on Beijing to resume exports.
the_headline: The World Needs Masks. China Makes Them — But Has Been Hoarding Them.

the_snippet: Georgia joins Louisiana as the second state to delay voting because of the coronavirus. Arizona, Florida, Illinois and Ohio are still set to vote on Tuesday.
the_headline: Georgia Postpones Its Primary as Virus Upends Voting

the_snippet: Scientists are ramping up the breeding of lab mice as well as the testing of primates and other animals, but it all takes time.
the_headline: These Lab Animals Will Help Fight Coronavirus

the_snippet: The number of confirmed cases in the state is now 613, including 269 in New York City, officials said.
the_headline: 2 New York State Lawmakers Test Positive for Coronavirus

the_snippet: At Camp 7, the military holds prisoners who were previously held and interrogated by the C.I.A. But in recent years, conditions have eased up a bit.
the_headline: Inside the Most Secret Place at Guantánamo Bay

the_snippet: The Music Issue, out on March 15, introduces a multimedia experience that bridges print and digital through your smartphone.
the_headline: Getting The New York Times Magazine to Jump Off the Page

the_snippet: Canceled games and tournaments were a major hit. Insurance policies and contracts can only help so much. No games mean no ticket sales and reduced media payments.
the_headline: The Financial Blow of the Coronavirus on Sports

the_snippet: Many companies are asking employees to work at home, and ridership is declining.
the_headline: Coronavirus in N.Y.: Riders Ditch the Subway as Fear Spreads

the_snippet: Mr. Gates, who founded the company with Paul Allen four decades ago, will also step down from the board of Berkshire Hathaway.
the_headline: Bill Gates Stepping Down From Microsoft’s Board

the_snippet: After criticizing American officials for politicizing the pandemic, Chinese officials and news outlets have floated unfounded theories that the United States was the source of the virus.
the_headline: China Spins Tale That the U.S. Army Started the Coronavirus Epidemic

the_snippet: The Communist Party is trying to fill the airwaves with positive stories about its battle against the virus. Chinese reporters, buoyed by widespread calls for free speech, are resisting.
the_headline: As China Cracks Down on Coronavirus Coverage, Journalists Fight Back
